reviewText:
Overview:Plug & Play is an Indie point-and-click adventure game developed by Swiss Mario von Rickenbach and Michael Frei, who coded and drew/animated it respectively; it is published by Etter Studio. It is based on the short film by the same name, created by Michael Frei. It's available on Steam, the App Store and Google Play Store. It has received various awards as a game and as a short film. The game is a casual, comical, and seemingly not too serious title. Nevertheless, it does have high levels of philosophical implications and symbolic imagery that may not be -and are most likely not- noticed by most people who play the game. The short film version conveys the core message in a much more direct way. It is an artistic expression. This game is about the human condition.


Story:The game has a very ambiguous and vague way of telling its story. At first glance it is a slightly vulgar game that has much apparent sexual innuendo, phallic and yonic symbols are also ever-present in the game and play an underlying, much more profound role than what they may represent at first sight.

A ‚Äòplugman‚Äô connects and disconnects with other ‚Äòplugmen‚Äô. They run, hit, get hit, touch, pull, push and converse with one another. You will laugh throughout all of this, since it‚Äôs an unexpectedly hilarious experience.


Gameplay:There‚Äôs not much to the gameplay, you click and drag objects and ‚Äòplugmen‚Äô, and hit switches which turn lights on and off.

Design-wise it expects you to get out of your comfort zone. Yes, it‚Äôs a fairly linear game, but there are parts of it that require you to try different things out, and the game doesn‚Äôt necessarily spell those things out for you.


Visual:It‚Äôs a significantly minimalist game. All there is are drawn characters, hands, and objects such as light switches, electrical plugs, cables that plug in, and cables that get plugged into.

The ‚Äòplugmen‚Äô are actually very well animated, it‚Äôs one of the first things I noticed and appreciated about the game. Animations are very comical and don‚Äôt take themselves too seriously, but are very fluid.


Sound:Most of the game is silent, unless you‚Äôre interacting with something or watching a sequence happen, and those sounds have a fairly high quality.

The beginning of the game has a choir singing, and it was actually a very pleasant choir, it gave the game a sense of duality. What I mean by duality is that the game seems so casual, not serious at all at first glance, and the choir gives it a kind of dramatic alien atmosphere that does feel very serious. I believe this is because the undisclosed themes that you have to read into -such as heartbreak, insecurity, and generally connecting with people- are actually very serious and very relatable to people as human beings.


Final Thoughts: When I first saw the game on my activity feed, I surely didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd end up writing a review for it; I was simply intrigued by its ‚Äúwhat-the-f***edness‚Äù. The first time I played it I laughed harder than I have in a while, and the second time I played it I almost teared up. I had to play the game twice to really understand the themes that it experiments with. Once I did understand I related to the game on an emotional level. I enjoyed it and found it almost cathartic by the end of my second playthrough, which led me to write this review.

This is very much a work of art in its own right, a manifestation of self-expression. The biggest theme (the way I see it) is human connection, that‚Äôs the whole point of the game in my opinion. The theme of human connection serves as an umbrella for several other themes. Themes of love, relationships, friendships, insecurity, indecisiveness, trust, heartbreak, and mostly behaviors towards and from other people. All of these things affect us as people, as human beings; this manifests everyday when we wake up in the morning and turn on the light. and when we turn the light off to go to sleep at night. This game is about the human condition.

BonusIf you think you might like the short yet enlightening experience of playing this game but are doubtful, watch my playthrough and decide. Either way, I do believe experiencing it first-hand is much more special than watching someone else go through it.

The playfulness of the vignettes that seem so mix matched and nonsensical trace intimate analogies into a collage of weirdness. I don‚Äôt know that I‚Äôd consider it especially adept or subtle in how it goes about this, but its sincere commitment to say something important while painting an amusingly offbeat, sex obsessed world is consistently entertaining and surprisingly considered. This is, as stated in their description, more an interactive animation than a game, and I think I spent about 12 minutes going through. Ultimately, if you're not really into weird little art pieces you probably shouldn't buy this and I probably wouldn't pay the full ¬£1.99 for it, but if it's on sale I say give it a gander.

reviewText:
To review Plug and Play is a really hard task, cause I have no idea how to review a game in which I have no idea what I'm doing, but I'm gonna give it my best shot, so here goes.

Plug and Play is a game about Plugs and love. There's no traditional story telling here as it's all random sequences which make up the entire game.

The gameplay consists of dragging and clicking the entire time. The entire game's goal is to plug something in or plug something out.

The art style is weird looking and it just creeps you out at first and then it weird's you out, how strange the game becomes in a short amount of time.

The game is also incredibly short. It took me 10 minutes to finish the entire game and after you finish the game the first time, there's no replay value what so ever, so keep that in mind if you're planning on buying this game.

In the end, there's not much to say about the game apart from what I already said.  Plug and Play is a great little art title and I highly suggest you check it out, but only on a discount since I recommend spending 3 euros for 10 minutes of content. I do suggest getting it on a discount though and you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Plug and Play is an interacive video with some interesting visuals and ideas but fails to impress with its limited amount of player involvement and extremely short run time.

The Good
Plug and Play is a simple game with hand-drawn style graphics and a minimalistic approach to conveying ideas, which it does do quite well. The actions that take place during the game can be metaphors for many aspects of life, such as love, jealousy, and death. These themes are conveyed in the simple graphics mentioned before, which is commendable as it manages to make you think about serious topics with visials that very loosely represent the things they could refer to.

The Bad
Although the game allows for deeper thought into its meaning, it was personally very forgetable. This is due mostly to the run time, which was only approximately 10 minutes. The game was over when I was just starting to think about any kind of story or meaning. Some may say that this means the game is a good length as it is just long enough to provoke deeper thought, but even if you believe that to be true, charging $2.99 seems overpriced for a game that could have been experienced almost the same as if it were a video. The only interaction you have is to click or pull certain items or options when promted. There is no replayability and no way to lose.

Although Plug and Play is an interesting experience, it is too short and without enough interactive elements to justify charging almost $3. While writiing this review, I actually found the video online which the game was adapted from, a 6 minute story featuring almost exactly the same scenes and ideas that the game had, but at no cost. The little interaction the game did have helped provoke me to think about its deeper meanings, but not enough for me to reccomend purchasing this game over watching the free video.

reviewText:
Plug and Play is an interacive video with some interesting visuals and ideas but fails to impress with its limited amount of player involvement and extremely short run time.

The Good
Plug and Play is a simple game with hand-drawn style graphics and a minimalistic approach to conveying ideas, which it does do quite well. The actions that take place during the game can be metaphors for many aspects of life, such as love, jealousy, and death. These themes are conveyed in the simple graphics mentioned before, which is commendable as it manages to make you think about serious topics with visials that very loosely represent the things they could refer to.

The Bad
Although the game allows for deeper thought into its meaning, it was personally very forgetable. This is due mostly to the run time, which was only approximately 10 minutes. The game was over when I was just starting to think about any kind of story or meaning. Some may say that this means the game is a good length as it is just long enough to provoke deeper thought, but even if you believe that to be true, charging $2.99 seems overpriced for a game that could have been experienced almost the same as if it were a video. The only interaction you have is to click or pull certain items or options when promted. There is no replayability and no way to lose.

Although Plug and Play is an interesting experience, it is too short and without enough interactive elements to justify charging almost $3. While writiing this review, I actually found the video online which the game was adapted from, a 6 minute story featuring almost exactly the same scenes and ideas that the game had, but at no cost. The little interaction the game did have helped provoke me to think about its deeper meanings, but not enough for me to reccomend purchasing this game over watching the free video.
